size.extreme wide shot: extreme wide shot that shows the environment on a grand scale, making the subject appear very small
size.bird’s-eye view: bird’s-eye view shot that looks straight down from above, emphasizing patterns and layout
size.wide shot: wide shot that captures the subject within a large portion of the environment
size.full shot: full shot that frames the subject from head to toe
size.medium full shot: medium full shot that frames the subject roughly from the knees up
size.medium shot: medium shot that frames the subject from the waist up
size.medium close-up: medium close-up that frames the subject from the chest or shoulders up
size.knee shot: knee shot that frames the subject from around the knees upward
size.waist shot: waist shot that frames the subject from the waist upward
size.close-up: close-up shot that emphasizes the subject’s face and expressions
size.extreme close-up: extreme close-up that focuses tightly on a specific detail, such as the eyes or mouth

focal_length.16mm: captured with a 16mm ultra-wide lens, exaggerating perspective and capturing a broad view of the environment
focal_length.24mm: captured with a 24mm wide lens, providing a wide field of view while keeping the subject readable
focal_length.35mm: captured with a 35mm lens, offering a natural and cinematic perspective
focal_length.50mm: captured with a 50mm standard lens, giving a natural, human-eye-like perspective
focal_length.85mm: captured with an 85mm telephoto lens, ideal for portraits with a softly blurred background
focal_length.135mm: captured with a 135mm telephoto lens, compressing the background and strongly isolating the subject
focal_length.custom: captured with a custom focal length, tuned to the desired composition and style

move.static: remains completely static with no movement
move.dolly in: dollies in, moving steadily closer to the subject
move.dolly out: dollies out, slowly pulling away from the subject
move.left pan: pans to the left, following or revealing the scene horizontally
move.right pan: pans to the right, following or revealing the scene horizontally
move.tilt up: tilts upward, revealing what is above the subject
move.tilt down: tilts downward, revealing what is below the subject
move.orbit: orbits smoothly clockwise around the subject to reveal different angles
move.handheld: moves in a handheld style, with subtle natural shake that feels immersive

direction.backward: moves backward, retreating from the subject
direction.up: moves upward, elevating the point of view
direction.down: moves downward, lowering the point of view

speed.very slow: moves very slowly, creating a calm, meditative feeling
speed.slow: moves slowly, allowing the viewer time to absorb the scene
speed.normal: moves at a natural, balanced speed
speed.fast: moves quickly, adding energy and intensity to the shot

move style.smooth: with smooth, controlled, and stable motion
move style.shaky: movement is slightly shaky, creating a handheld, documentary-like feeling

transition_duration.very slow: shifts extremely slowly, creating a dreamy, gradual transition
transition_duration.slow: shifts slowly, allowing the viewer to notice the change clearly
transition_duration.normal: shifts at a natural, balanced speed
transition_duration.fast: shifts quickly, adding a sense of urgency or energy

type.subject focus: remains locked on the main subject
type.foreground focus: is on objects in the foreground, with the background softly blurred
type.background focus: is on the background, leaving the subject slightly out of focus
type.rack focus: shifts smoothly between the foreground and background
type.center focus: remains locked sharp on the subject at the center of the frame

depth.shallow: A shallow depth of field isolates the subject with a strong background blur
depth.medium: A medium depth of field keeps the subject clear while retaining some background detail
depth.deep: A deep depth of field keeps the entire scene in sharp focus
